posts.name:
Ronen R. Pessar
Ronen R. Pessar
posts.content:
Ever wonder why some crush cold calling but others fail? 

It's because of how interesting they are...

Every product falls on the innovation-commodity spectrum
â†³ your product's positioning (how the market sees it)

Let's break it down:

1. ğ—œğ—»ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ƒğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—½ğ—®ğ—»ğ—¶ğ—²ğ˜€: VERY interesting

These companies are obscure and their technology is often unknown.

Cold calling for them involves a lot of education.

For instance, when I worked with Stylo, we had a language model for customer support that auto-detected customer sentiment based on how the support ticket was written. No one had heard of it before.

Every call was about educating prospects. I would say, "Imagine getting feedback on every customer interaction without sending surveys."

This approach makes cold calling easier because what you say is inherently ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´.


2. ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—ºğ—¼ğ—±ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—½ğ—®ğ—»ğ—¶ğ—²ğ˜€:

These companies compete primarily on price.

Their products are well-known and not much different from competitors.

When cold calling for them, it's all about timing or a better price.

You ask, "Is it the right time?" or "Would you consider a cheaper alternative?"

Consistency and good follow-up are key.


Use this understanding-- where a product sits on this spectrum -- to tailor your script.

For innovative products, focus on education and showing the 10x value.

For commodities, focus on timing and cost-effectiveness.

Know your product.
Tailor your strategy.

Achieve better results.

posts.name:
Ken Morris
Ken Morris
posts.content:
ğƒğ-ğ«ğ¢ğ¬ğ¤ğ¢ğ§ğ  ğ˜ğ¨ğ®ğ« ğ’ğ­ğšğ«ğ­ğ®ğ© ğšğ­ ğ„ğ¯ğğ«ğ² ğ’ğ­ğšğ ğ: ğ€ ğ…ğ¨ğ®ğ§ğğğ«â€™ğ¬ ğ†ğ®ğ¢ğğ
The goal of VC and investors is not to "believe in your idea despite all risks".
The goal is to find a high-growth, high-risk opportunity and de-risk it as much as possible at every step.

If you're a founder looking to scale a successful startupâ€” understanding the investors' POV can help you avoid common pitfalls and raise VC capital faster.

From inception through to maturity, every step comes with its unique focus and a new set of potential pitfalls.

Visualization by:

ğğ«ğ-ğ’ğğğ ğ’ğ­ğšğ ğ: Tackling Technical Risks
At this preliminary stage, the focus is primarily on product development and addressing technical risks. Focus on: the feasibility, scalability, and potential production costs of your product.
ï¸ Without wanting to tout my own horn, partnering with an experienced team likemay be the best strategy to derisk your startup at this stage. Bringing in talent who has DONE the very thing you're trying to do before will be your best shot at minimizing technical risk.

ğ’ğğğ ğ’ğ­ğšğ ğ: Navigating Market Validation and Early Adoption
At the seed stage the focus shifts to the market. Primary challenge: product-market fit. By understanding your potential customers, conducting market research, and collecting feedback from early adopters, you can validate your startup's business model and mitigate risks associated with market acceptance.

ğ’ğğ«ğ¢ğğ¬ ğ€: Scaling and Executing
Upon securing Series A funding, it's time to scale. Risk: growth and lack of traction. Here, startups need to identify effective customer acquisition channels, streamline their marketing and sales strategies, and establish a scalable sales pipeline while maintaining service/product quality.

ğ’ğğ«ğ¢ğğ¬ ğ: Expanding and Competing
At the Series B stage startups tend to enter new markets, expand geographically, or target new customer segments. As you spread your wings, you'll likely face increased competition and potential regulatory challenges. Challenge: balancing aggressive growth with maintaining operational efficiency to succeed at this stage.

ğ’ğğ«ğ¢ğğ¬ ğ‚ ğšğ§ğ ğğğ²ğ¨ğ§ğ: Sustaining Culture and Scaling Operations
With Series C and beyond, the focus is on scaling operations on a larger scale and fostering a robust organizational culture.

Remember, while these risks tend to fit each stage, the startup journey is rarely linear.

The No. 1 way to mitigate these risks (at any stage) = ğ’‰ğ’‚ğ’—ğ’Šğ’ğ’ˆ ğ’‚ğ’„ğ’„ğ’†ğ’”ğ’” ğ’•ğ’ ğ’•ğ’‚ğ’ğ’†ğ’ğ’• ğ’˜ğ’‰ğ’ ğ’‰ğ’‚ğ’” ğ’ˆğ’ğ’ğ’† ğ’•ğ’‰ğ’“ğ’ğ’–ğ’ˆğ’‰ ğ’•ğ’‰ğ’† ğ’‹ğ’ğ’–ğ’“ğ’ğ’†ğ’š ğ’ƒğ’†ğ’‡ğ’ğ’“ğ’†.

You don't want to work with a tech team who has never worked on a high-growth tech startup even if they are an excellent programmer.

ï¸ If you're a business founder looking to get an MVP built or hire a CTO DM me for info! Our team has built hundreds of MVPs over the years and we know how to scale ideas together.

Identifying and addressing these risks early not only helps founders build investor confidence but also lays a stronger foundation for sustainable growth.

Edward Schaefer
Edward Schaefer
posts.content:
Feeling drained by endless notifications and screen time? It might be time for a digital detox.  Imagine a few hours of uninterrupted calm, free from the constant ping of alertsâ€”what would that feel like? This Saturday, I invite you to find out.

We live in a world where screens dominate our time, often at the expense of our mental and emotional well-being. Research shows that reducing screen time improves sleep, decreases stress, and even enhances our ability to focus. But stepping away isnâ€™t always easy. Start small: try turning off notifications, leaving your phone in another room, or setting a â€œdigital sunsetâ€ when you log off for the evening. Notice how your mind feels without the buzz of distractions.

This weekend, give yourself the gift of stillness. Replace scrolling with a mindful walk, reading a physical book, or simply savoring the quiet. Your leadership and well-being thrive when you take time to recharge. If youâ€™re reading this on a Saturday or Sunday, consider it your reminder to log off and reconnect with yourself. How will you spend your screen-free time today?

Hi, I'm Edward Schaefer, a leadership coach focused on leadership, culture, strategy, systems, and change. I believe that effective leadership starts with a healthy, well-rested mind and a heart that's connected to what matters most.
This post is part of my
seriesâ€”a collection designed to help you pause, reflect, and recharge. If you found this helpful, please like, comment, or share it with others who might benefit from a reminder to rest and care for themselves. Follow me for more insights on leadership and well-being, and if you'd like to explore coaching together, reach outâ€”I'm here to support your growth, both as a leader and as a person.

comments.commentText:
Taking a moment to share my own experience with digital detox: I started implementing a 'digital sunset' where I log off all devices an hour before bed. At first, it felt challengingâ€”almost like I was missing out. But over time, Iâ€™ve noticed better sleep, clearer thinking, and a sense of calm I didnâ€™t realize I was missing.

If youâ€™ve tried something similar or have your own strategies for managing screen time, Iâ€™d love to hear about them. How do you unplug and recharge? Letâ€™s share ideas and inspire each other!

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely love this reminder, Edward! A digital detox is a game-changer for clarity and focus. Looking forward to embracing the calm! ğŸŒŸ

posts.content:
The Fear of Disconnecting 

Have you ever felt uneasy about stepping away from the constant buzz of emails, notifications, and social media?  The fear of disconnecting isnâ€™t just about missing outâ€”itâ€™s about losing a sense of control in a hyper-connected world.

But hereâ€™s the irony: True control comes from knowing when to pause.
Disconnecting doesnâ€™t mean running away; it means recharging, reflecting, and reconnecting with what truly matters. 

Try this:
 Set a â€œno-screenâ€ hour each day.
 Engage in an activity that doesnâ€™t involve technology.
 Reflect on how it feels to be present with your thoughts.

Silence isnâ€™t emptyâ€”itâ€™s full of answers. Whatâ€™s your favorite way to unplug and reconnect with yourself? Share your thoughts below!

comments.commentText: True digital wellness isn't going offline - it's being intentional online.

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! A no-screen hour sounds refreshing. I love journaling during that time to enhance self-reflection and creativity!

posts.name:
Business Development - The Missing Link Between Marketing & Sales - 540,000 Members Strong
Business Development - The Missing Link Between Marketing & Sales - 540,000 Members Strong
posts.content:
Hire for character. Train for skill. 

ğ—¦ğ—¸ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ˜€ ğ—°ğ—®ğ—» ğ—¯ğ—² ğ˜ğ—®ğ˜‚ğ—´ğ—µğ˜. 
ğ—œğ—»ğ˜ğ—²ğ—´ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜†, ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—¸ ğ—²ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ—°, ğ—®ğ—»ğ—± ğ—µğ˜‚ğ—ºğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† ğ—°ğ—®ğ—»ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜.

As Warren Buffett said,
â€œLook for three things: integrity, intelligence, and energy.
If they donâ€™t have the first, the other two will kill you.â€

Hereâ€™s the risk of hiring a skilled, low-character person:
- They cut corners when no one is watching.
- They disrupt team morale with selfish behavior.
- They resist feedback and blame others for mistakes.
- Their ego overshadows the mission.

Now, imagine someone with great character but less experience:
- They show up ready to learn every day.
- They lift others with their positive attitude.
- They own their mistakes and grow from them.
- They value the teamâ€™s success over their own.

The difference is clear.
Character builds trust, and trust builds teams.

Skills get the job done today.
Character builds a legacy for tomorrow.

Do you agree?
How do you approach hiring for character?

comments.commentText: Thank you, Fabio Invernizzi - Change Management! Glad you found it insightful!

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Hiring for character fosters a thriving culture. Skills can be taught, but integrity and teamwork are irreplaceable. ğŸŒŸ

posts.name:
Michael Ocean
Michael Ocean
posts.content:
"A fool with a tool is still a fool"

Just wrapped up an insightful conversation with Jon Fraser(Chief Growth Officer at Dasro Tech Talent, former leader at Omniconvert and The App Labb) who shared a truth about tech implementation that most leaders overlook:


Having the best tools doesn't guarantee success - it's all about the 'why' behind using them.


Here are the hard questions every leader should ask before their next tech investment:


- Are we teaching our teams HOW to use tools, or WHY they need them?
- Is poor tool adoption really about the tool, or about incomplete onboarding?
- Have we created an environment where tools enable continuous improvement?


In the full episode, we explored:


- Building alignment between sales, marketing, and CS teams
- Creating effective change management strategies
- Why training without context is bound to fail
- Approaches to evaluating new technology investments
- The importance of continuous tool evolution


Jon's 25 years of experience leading growth initiatives taught him that tools should be "living breathing organisms" - not static solutions.


Check out the full conversation in the comments

comments.commentText:
I love what Jon said: "If an executive team is not involved in messaging, there's something wrong. The buck stops with them. If they're not in there as part of the process, they should be somewhere else." Now that's a wake-up call about leadership accountability.

Full episode:

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely, Jon! Its crucial to focus on the whyâ€”tools are only as effective as the mindset and training behind them. Great insights!
